div.l: He pⁱrikketh harde and depe as he were madde
This Ioly lyf haue these ij clerkꝭes ladde
Tyll that þe iii kok bygan̄ to syng
¶ Aleyn̄ waxe wery in the dawnynge
For he had swonken̄ all the long nyȝte
And seid fare well Malyn̄ swete wyght
The day ys com̄e y may no leng̉er byde
But eủer mor͗e where so y go or ryde
Y am thyn own̄ so haue y sele
Now dere lēmman̄ quoth sche go fare well
But ar þᵘou goo one thyng y wol the tell
Whan̄ þat þᵘou wendest homward by the mylle
Ryght at þe Entre of the dor͗e byhynde
Thou schalt a kake of half a buschell Fynde
That was made of thyn̄ own̄ mele
Which þat y helpe my sir͗e for to stele
And gode lēmman god þe saue ⁊and kepe
And with þat word almost sche gan̄ to wepe
Aleyn̄ upryseth and thought or þat hit dawe
I woll go crepe in by my Felowe
And fond þe cradel with his hond anon̄e
By god quoth he all wrong y haue myssegon̄
My hede is toty of my swynk to nyȝte
That maketh me þat y go not aryght
Y wote well by the cradel y haue myssegoo
For her͗e lyeth þe myller and his wyf also
And forth he goth on develeway
Vn to the bedde þer as þe myller lay
He wende haue cropen̄ in by his felow Iohn
And by þe myller in he crepe anon̄e
And kaught hym by the nekke and softe he spak
He seid þᵘou Iohn þᵘou swyneshed awake
For cⁱristꝭes fale and her͗e a fyn̄ game
For by þat lord þat called ys seynt Iame
